question: 5 (c)
sols_latex:
A= ones(100,1)

for n=1:99

A={[}X.\^{}n A{]};

end

a= A'*A\textbackslash{}A'*Y

plot(X,Y,'or')

hold on

XX=linspace(X(1),X(100),1000);

plot(XX,a(1)*XX.\^{}2+a(2)*XX=C3*ones(1,length(XX)))
sols_raw:
A= ones(100,1)

for n=1:99

A=[X.^n A];

end

a= A'*A\A'*Y	

plot(X,Y,'or')

hold on

XX=linspace(X(1),X(100),1000);

plot(XX,a(1)*XX.^2+a(2)*XX=C3*ones(1,length(XX)))
statement_html:
You are given a set of 100 data points (xn, yn) with xn increasing.

(c) Suppose instead that you choose to make a least square fit of the data points to a quadratic polynomial

\[\begin{aligned} \displaystyle f(x) = c_0x^2 + c_1x + c_2.\end{aligned}\]

Write down the MATLAB/Octave command you would use to calculate the coefficients, plot the original data points and plot the quadratic fit (you may assume that vectors \(X = [x_1, x_2, \dots, x_N]^T\) and \(Y = [y_1, y_2, \dots, y_N]^T\) have already been defined).
statement_latex:
You are given a set of 100 data points \emph{(x\textsubscript{n},
y\textsubscript{n})} with \emph{x\textsubscript{n}} increasing.

\textbf{(c)} Suppose instead that you choose to make a least square fit
of the data points to a quadratic polynomial

\begin{align*}
\displaystyle
f(x) = c_0x^2 + c_1x + c_2.
\end{align*}

Write down the MATLAB/Octave command you would use to calculate the
coefficients, plot the original data points and plot the quadratic fit
(you may assume that vectors $X = [x_1, x_2, \dots, x_N]^T$ and
$Y = [y_1, y_2, \dots, y_N]^T$ have already been defined).
statement_raw:
You are given a set of 100 data points ''(x<sub>n</sub>, y<sub>n</sub>)'' with ''x<sub>n</sub>'' increasing.

'''(c)''' Suppose instead that you choose to make a least square fit of the data points to a quadratic polynomial

:<math>\displaystyle
f(x) = c_0x^2 + c_1x + c_2.
</math>

Write down the MATLAB/Octave command you would use to calculate the coefficients, plot the original data points and plot the quadratic fit (you may assume that vectors <math>X = [x_1, x_2, \dots, x_N]^T</math> and <math>Y = [y_1, y_2, \dots, y_N]^T</math> have already been defined).
